The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

And this taske they were pleaÅ¿ed to lay upon me. Who albeit I do, and cannot but ingenuouÅ¿ly acknowledge my Å¿elf one of the leaÅ¿t and weakeÅ¿t Servants of ChriÅ¿t, and that many others there are in this Church, who might far more worthily acquit themÅ¿elves in this Å¿ervice: Yet durÅ¿t not withÅ¿tand the motion, having Å¿o clear a Calling, and conÅ¿idering withall how I Å¿tand oblidged, in my Å¿tation, to maintain the true Religion, in Doctrine, WorÅ¿hip, DiÅ¿cipline and Government, by the mercy of God eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed amongÅ¿t us, in common with the reÅ¿t of the Lords people in the Land, by Solemn Vow and Covenant, and more particularly

The perÅ¿onall obligations which you have laid upon me by a continued tract of undeÅ¿erved reÅ¿pects, ever Å¿ince the firÅ¿t time I was known to your LordÅ¿hip, would require a worthier teÅ¿timony of acknowledgment, then is this mean preÅ¿ent, or any thing elÅ¿e my Å¿mall Å¿tore of abilities can afford. But to Å¿peak truth, it is not Å¿o much any perÅ¿onall concernment that hath engaged my heart to your LordÅ¿hip, as that which hath endeared you to all who know the truth and you: That grace which God hath vouchÅ¿afed upon you to walk in tenderneÅ¿Å¿e and cloÅ¿eneÅ¿Å¿e with himÅ¿elf in your privat courÅ¿e and with

The one touching the qualifications of the perÅ¿ons that are to be acknowledged members of his ViÅ¿ible Church, and Å¿o, in effect, comes to be a QueÅ¿tion de Å¿inibus, of the marches of his ViÅ¿ible Kingdom: The other touching the matter and way of the externall ViÅ¿ible Government thereof.

In the former part of this Examination, my labour is to diÅ¿cover the unwarrantablneÅ¿Å¿e and contrariety of this Tenent, to the Word of God; And to Å¿hew that all who being of years does Å¿eriouÅ¿ly profeÅ¿Å¿e the ChriÅ¿tian faith, and Å¿ubjection to be diÅ¿ciplin'd and governed by the Ordinances of ChriÅ¿t, ought to be admitted into the fellowÅ¿hip of his ViÅ¿ible Church, without any neceÅ¿Å¿ity of puting them to a triall touching their inward Å¿pirituall eÅ¿tate, and judging upon the Å¿ame whether regenerat or not, as to that effect: And are to be dealt with, by PaÅ¿tours and privat ChriÅ¿tians in their reÅ¿pective wayes as theÅ¿e that are ã in non-Latin alphabet ã within, 1 Cor. 5. 12. div.p: section 1 THe Author as he picked out Å¿ome of the places of Scripture brought by the oppoÅ¿ites of his way to prove the powe â¢ of the Church Government to be in the hands of Church Officers only (and they are but a few of many and only concerning a particular Act of Government, Ordination, when as they bring many pregnant proofs from Scripture for the whole power of Government in generall,) Å¿o he is pleaÅ¿ed to pick out at his pleaÅ¿ure Å¿ome few of their Arguments by way of reaÅ¿on.

section 4 2. Obj. But is not this confuÅ¿ion, for all to have an hand in theÅ¿e great things? This abÅ¿urdity is moÅ¿t juÅ¿tly charged upon your way of Government. section 5 No: 'Tis not confuÅ¿ion: The Church being conÅ¿idered as an organicall body, the power of acting may be fundamentally and intrinÅ¿ecally in the whole, and yet each organ move orderly in his diÅ¿tinct place, and way. section 6 I humbly conceive the Author had done better to have Å¿pared his phyÅ¿iologick Å¿imile here, and am of the mind Å¿ome of his late aÅ¿Å¿ociats here, will not comply with his phyÅ¿icall conceptions, whatever they eÅ¿teem of his theologicall Tenets. Å¿imile to tell us of powers or faculties in the whole Å¿oul originally? Is the Å¿oul an organicall body? But may Å¿ome Å¿ay, the Author Å¿aith, the Å¿enÅ¿itive faculties are in all the Å¿oul fundamentally, and radically, and the Å¿oul radically and fundamentally in all the body, and Å¿o would
by conÅ¿equence Å¿ay that the Å¿enÅ¿itive faculties are in the whole body fundamentally, and radically. AnÅ¿w. 1.
